stories.name: The Onager, the Donkey, and the Driver

posts.author: Onager

comments.author: Donkey
comments.body: Yo, cousin. Feel the caress of the sun with me.

comments.author: Onager
comments.body: O-K sure. By the way, I’m impressed by your pelt and your teeth. You look way more in shape than I do. Where do you workout?

comments.author: Donkey
comments.body: I barely workout. It’s all because of my diet.

comments.author: Onager
comments.body: Where do you get all that food?

comments.author: Donkey
comments.body: My master, the driver? He feeds me

comments.author: Onager
comments.body: Sheeht man, that's great. I'm soooo envious

posts.body: Man it’s hot out here. I wish I could find something nice to eat today… I haven’t eaten anything but grass for days. Oh, hey, it’s Donkey.

posts.author: Onager
posts.body: The sun is hot and I’m walking alone in the plains. I wonder what Donkey’s doing?

posts.author: Onager

comments.author: Donkey
comments.body: But cousin, the food is worth. Remember how nice my pelt and teeth are!

comments.author: Onager
comments.body: Nah, cousin, your pelt and teeth don’t look so nice with that man swinging his club at your ass all day long.

comments.author: Driver
comments.body: As long as he eats, he don’t care. Now move along, unless you want to carry some of that load too!

posts.body: I’m going to take back what I said, Donkey. I don’t care about how good your diet is, if you have to go through that slavery. That’s too high a price--even for a donkey.

posts.author: Narrator
posts.body: 300 BCE. The sun is high, and an onager is walking on a mellow boulevard to an unimportant destination. But what stands on the horizon? Is it a donkey? Here is a tale of exchanging much for a life of security.

posts.author: Narrator
posts.body: He’s on a good break, happiest as a donkey can be, and the sunshine envelops his full being and form, agreeing with his every step.

posts.author: Narrator
posts.body: The Donkey approaches the horizon again, but this time with a load on his back, a driver beating him on the ass with a club.

posts.author: Narrator
posts.body: And just the same is with our lives - with a belly full of knowledge of security, we may fail to properly assess important details of our existence that must be valued too, such as freedom, and pursuing a good life.

posts.author: Donkey
posts.body: I think that, well, I'm on the bright side of things.

posts.author: Donkey
posts.body: My life for a bargain? I don't think so. I have everything I want.

posts.author: Donkey

comments.author: Onager
comments.body: I may be unsated, but at least I have my freedom with me!

comments.author: Donkey
comments.body: What is the value of freedom if you have to starve?

comments.author: Onager
comments.body: A freedom so forgotten that it also forgot its price: the loss of your dignity.

comments.author: Donkey
comments.body: Dignity has no gain for a donkey!

posts.body: What foolishness are you playing? See how I am well-fed by my master.

posts.author: Narrator
posts.body: 300 BCE. The sun is high, and a Donkey is walking on a mellow boulevard to an unimportant destination. But what stands on the horizon? Is it an Onager? Here is a tale of valuing freedom little, in exchange for a life of security.

posts.author: Narrator
posts.body: The thought crossed his mind more than once, like a misplaced item.

posts.author: Narrator
posts.body: An onager approaches the horizon, looking thirsty and hungry simultaenously. The Donkey could barely stare at the poor animal.

posts.author: Narrator
posts.body: And the Donkey was satisfied with his elected fate. The Onager died of starvation a few days later--the Donkey who passed him by did not so much as glance his way.

stories.name: The Donkey, the Onager, and the Lion

posts.author: Onager
posts.body: Wow, that looks like slavery to me. I guess I’m lucky after all, compared to him. That’s right, I have grass near the hillsides, while you need someone to feed you while being mistreated like that.

posts.author: Narrator
posts.body: 300 BCE. The onager saw his friend the Donkey squirming from repeated blows to his ass, as the Driver made him carry a load so heavy that his progress ahead was inches and tears.

posts.author: Narrator
posts.body: At that very moment, a lion appeared at the scene.

posts.author: Lion

comments.author: Donkey
comments.body: Not me! Look, my driver is standing next to me. He’s got a mean club!

comments.author: Onager
comments.body: Please, non, he’s been eating a better diet than me, so that means he’s tastier!

posts.body: I wonder who I’m going to eat today. Who’s going to end up in my stomach? Who?

posts.author: Lion
posts.body: Poor onager. You don’t have anyone around to protect you?

posts.author: Narrator
posts.body: And so the onager was devoured by the lion because he was all alone.

posts.author: Narrator
posts.body: So it is too with our lives - we may decide that the price of freedom is too high and value our independence stubbornly, but that may also come at a price when the danger comes. Breaking out of our stubbornness and asking for assistance may save our lives. So: are you the onager, or the donkey?

stories.name: The Frogs and the Battle of the Bulls

posts.author: Frog

comments.author: Frog 2
comments.body: Have you checked with the neighbors? Maybe they’re responsible for all this ruckus.

comments.author: Frog
comments.body: No, they’re on vacation dear. I think it’s something else outside. Beyond the pond, I mean.

comments.author: Frog 2
comments.body: Well then, what are you waiting for? You poo-wit, go check it out, and tell us what’s going on already!

posts.body: What is this low tremor in the ground? Why are the lilies sinking and the dragonflies departing so suddenly?

posts.author: Frog

comments.author: Frog 2
comments.body: Oh that’s it? What’s the big deal? The rich bulls’ place is pretty far from here, ain’t it?

comments.author: Frog
comments.body: No, that’s not the problem. Look, come with me and you’ll understand.

posts.body: Well, that sure breaks the routine. Ribbit. I recognize these bulls. My gosh. They're the bulls that control half of the meadow. This is bad news.

posts.author: The Eye
posts.body: PIC-f12-4

posts.author: Frog
posts.body: The bulls are fighting each other. That is bad news. From the tremors and noise, the lilies are being squished to the sides of the pond. The dragonflies are flying off, and the butterflies are quivering back to the woods. Our very lifestyle is being threatened.

posts.author: Frog

comments.author: Frog
comments.body: Who cares if our homes are destroyed - when that bull comes down on us, we’ll be trampled to death!

posts.body: Goodbye, my home.

posts.author: Narrator
posts.body: What is the balance of the world, if not imbalance? This is a tale that proves the following: When rich and powerful people fight one another, it is the poor that ultimately pay the price.

posts.author: Narrator
posts.body: And suddenly, the bull who was losing the fight turned around and charged off. Towards the pond.

posts.author: Narrator
posts.body: And thus the bull who lost the fight destroyed all the lilies in the pond, and in a rush of panic, crushed the frogs’ homes as well as the frogs, who had attempted to leap away in vain.

stories.name: The Fox, the Lion, and the Footprints

posts.author: Fox
posts.body: Why are all the animals going in that cave? I wonder if there’s anything important going on.

posts.author: Fox

comments.author: Goose
comments.body: The lion has grown sick. We’re trying to smooze up to him while we can.

comments.author: Turtle
comments.body: You mean lick his stinky fur, to get his favor? You’ll need a bigger tongue for that, pal! You can’t lick it up for all of us, no you can’t!

comments.author: Cat
comments.body: That’s right, I’ll lick him more!

comments.author: Fox
comments.body: What a bunch of weirdos. Wait… I’ve got a suspicion…

posts.body: Hey, you! Can you tell me what’s going on over there?

posts.author: Fox
posts.body: Because I can see that the tracks are going in, but that none are going out.

posts.author: Narrator
posts.body: An old lion was getting old and weak, and he was not getting any less hungry.

posts.author: Lion
posts.body: I know what I’m going to do: I’ll pretend I’m sick, then the idiots are going to come pay their respect and wish me well so that I don’t eat them up later. But then… I’ll do just the opposite, hehehehehehehehe

posts.author: Narrator
posts.body: The fox approached the mouth of the cave, careful to look around her as she threaded. The lion saw her and immediately smiled.

posts.author: The Eye
posts.body: PIC-f18-6

posts.author: Lion
posts.body: Hey, fox. Did you come to visit me? I won’t forget it. It’s quite dark here. Why don’t you come inside?

posts.author: Narrator
posts.body: Other people’s mistakes can often save us from making them.
